title: NetBSD 10: Thirty Years, Still Going Strong

Best physical engineer thing you’ve bought that’s made a difference
description:
We all spend inordinate amounts of money on computer hardware, books, digital tools, IDEs, services, and loads of other ephemeral, intangible things that provide us varying degrees of quality of life improvements, learning, and productivity gains,

But what physical / tangible things have you bought that have made a significant improvement in productivity, understanding and working through complex problems, or just otherwise improved your ability to design, and engineer whatever it is you work in.

It could be a special pen? Maybe some lesser known niche notebook, a specific mouse.

Im redoing my home office and I’m interested in hearing what physical, well-being related, comfort, health, or otherwise important thing lobsters has spent their hard earned pennies on.
description_plain:
We all spend inordinate amounts of money on computer hardware, books, digital tools, IDEs, services, and loads of other ephemeral, intangible things that provide us varying degrees of quality of life improvements, learning, and productivity gains,

It could be a special pen? Maybe some lesser known niche notebook, a specific mouse. 

Im redoing my home office and I’m interested in hearing what physical, well-being related, comfort, health, or otherwise important thing lobsters has spent their hard earned pennies on.

Proposal to add a "robotics" tag to Lobsters
description:
Hi, I don’t know if this is the proper way to propose a new tag but it seems like the most natural approach. Robotics seems like a field very well aligned with the Lobsters spirit. And I think the field is sufficiently different from existing tags to warrant a new tag. Last, there are probably people who want to specifically follow robotics-related stories. Ergo vis-a-vis concordantly let’s add a new tag??

Relevant posts / comments:

  • Notes on Cruise’s pedestrain accident
  • Reflecting on my robotics code from 2009
  • My $500M Mars Rover mistake
  • Fast symbolic computation for robotics
  • Browser-based simulator for robot dog
  • Coroutines make robot code easy
  • How to be a better roboticist
  • Towards helpful robots
  • Slitherbot
  • Open Dynamic Robot Initiative
  • Talk to your robot with Forth
  • Origin of robot arm programming languages
  • Science and engineering for learning robots

I can keep going but that’s probably good enough for now… https://lobste.rs/search?q=robot&what=stories&order=newest
description_plain:
Hi, I don't know if this is the proper way to propose a new tag but it seems like the most natural approach. Robotics seems like a field very well aligned with the Lobsters spirit. And I think the field is sufficiently different from existing tags to warrant a new tag. Last, there are probably people who want to specifically follow robotics-related stories. [Ergo vis-a-vis concordantly](https://youtu.be/hexboP623KQ?si=ztAnYjO2yvZdiVv0&t=8) let's add a new tag??

Relevant posts / comments:

* [Notes on Cruise's pedestrain accident](https://lobste.rs/s/osjvni/notes_on_cruise_s_pedestrian_accident)
* [Reflecting on my robotics code from 2009](https://lobste.rs/s/sqp3oy/annotating_reflecting_on_my_robotics)
* [My $500M Mars Rover mistake](https://lobste.rs/s/yqj3ae/my_500m_mars_rover_mistake_failure_story)
* [Fast symbolic computation for robotics](https://lobste.rs/s/qcsntm/fast_symbolic_computation_for_robotics)
* [Browser-based simulator for robot dog](https://lobste.rs/s/oyqonl/browser_based_simulator_for_petoi_bittle)
* [Coroutines make robot code easy](https://lobste.rs/s/bqqzyh/coroutines_make_robot_code_easy)
* [How to be a better roboticist](https://lobste.rs/s/eusaxy/how_be_better_roboticist)
* [Towards helpful robots](https://lobste.rs/s/eb1aqb/towards_helpful_robots_grounding)
* [Slitherbot](https://lobste.rs/s/iqjwos/slitherbot_snake_robot_with_3d_printed)
* [Open Dynamic Robot Initiative](https://lobste.rs/s/8xv71u/open_dynamic_robot_initiative)
* [Talk to your robot with Forth](https://lobste.rs/s/aw5tmx/talk_your_robot_with_forth_1984)
* [Origin of robot arm programming languages](https://lobste.rs/s/5syv3w/origin_robot_arm_programming_languages)
* [Science and engineering for learning robots](https://lobste.rs/s/rurfmx/science_engineering_for_learning_robots)

I can keep going but that's probably good enough for now... https://lobste.rs/search?q=robot&what=stories&order=newest

title: Letlang, written in Rust, targeting Rust, now has a specification
description:
Letlang is a hobby functional programming language. Its compiler is written in Rust and targets Rust (instead of LLVM, or C, or assembly). Mainly because it made it far easier to implement the runtime.

I had a working (unfinished) proof of concept, but I was always forgetting stuff and did not have a lot of free time to keep my mental model intact. Therefore I started writing a specification, which allowed me to simplify the syntax and semantics of the language, and find bugs in my implementation.

I wrote about it in details on my blog: here.

Thank you in advance for the feedback :)
description_plain:
Letlang is a hobby functional programming language. Its compiler is written in Rust and targets Rust (instead of LLVM, or C, or assembly). Mainly because it made it far easier to implement the runtime.

I had a working (unfinished) proof of concept, but I was always forgetting stuff and did not have a lot of free time to keep my mental model intact. Therefore I started writing a specification, which allowed me to simplify the syntax and semantics of the language, and find bugs in my implementation.

I wrote about it in details on my blog: [here](https://david-delassus.medium.com/letlang-specification-finalized-ea55fce4bbbe?sk=59d7ec3cc0aba0945c9e297e709c3c46).

Thank you in advance for the feedback :)
